docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "A Double Standard in Health Coverage" (March 17) was on the mark, but it did not discuss how the differences in health coverage between company executives and rank-and-file workers affect the nation's children.

headline.main: When It Comes to Health, Remember the Children

docs.snippet: To the Editor:         "A Double Standard in Health Coverage" (March 17) was on the mark, but it did not discuss how the differences in health coverage between company executives and rank-and-file workers affect the nation's children.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Europe in the throes of a widespread debate over its economic future, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced a plan today for long-heralded cuts in Germany's vaunted and well-padded welfare state that threaten social benefits that his compatriots have come to regard as virtually sacrosanct. The proposals, intended to reduce Germany's budget deficit by some $33 billion, reflected a broader sense in Europe that leaner times lie ahead for nations, led by Germany, that are working to fulfill the economic conditions for a single European currency.

headline.main: Kohl Offers Plan for Big Cuts In the German Welfare State

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy today accused Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, of trying to "sink the bill" approved by the Senate this week that would make health insurance more accessible. As the Senate's representatives on a conference committee to resolve differences between House and Senate versions of the insurance bill, Mr. Dole wanted to appoint a group of senators who favor medical savings accounts, a provision the Senate rejected 52 to 46. The House included the accounts in the version of the bill it passed last month.

docs.lead_paragraph: Longstanding contract disputes between Rutgers University and four of its faculty and staff unions flared into the open today with a noisy demonstration outside the president's office and barbed comments at a hearing on proposed tuition increases. Leaders of the unions said the lack of a contract after more than a year of bargaining meant that about 8,000 faculty members, lecturers, clerical workers and custodians could start taking job actions soon. They said those actions could include picketing the May 16 commencement or going on strike.

headline.main: Frustration Over Contract Talks at Rutgers Erupts Into Protest

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have given permission to St. Barnabas Medical Center and seven other hospitals in northern and central New Jersey to merge as the wave of hospital consolidations that has been taking place in much of the country begins to be felt in the state. The new company, St. Barnabas Health Care System, will be New Jersey's largest hospital corporation, with 3,200 beds, 4,000 affiliated physicians and more than one million patients. Although the center of the company will be the eight hospitals, the company will also administer six nursing homes, five clinics and three geriatric-care centers. The network, stretching from Passaic County to Ocean County, is expected to generate $1.5 billion a year in revenues.

headline.main: U.S. Agency Clears Merger For Hospitals

docs.lead_paragraph: The French Government today announced sweeping changes in the national health care system that are intended to curb spending and help tame the budget deficit. The new measures, among other things, will use computers to monitor every patient's costs and penalize doctors who surpass budgets for the care and prescriptions they provide. The changes announced today, which have been under public discussion since last fall, are almost sure to pass Parliament in the coming weeks and then would take effect immediately. They amount to the most far-reaching changes in 50 years for the state-run health care system here, and reflect the same struggle to rein in health costs seen in other countries like Britain, Germany and the United States.

headline.main: In France, Socialized Medicine Meets Gallic Version of H.M.O.
